title: How to Make Garlic Knots

methods.name: Making Garlic Knots Using Refrigerated Biscuits

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare the sheets.
steps.description:
Turn the oven on to 400 degrees F (200 C). Get out a baking sheet and spray it with cooking spray or line with parchment paper. This will prevent the garlic knots from sticking. Set the sheet aside while you make the garlic knots. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/04\/Make-Garlic-Knots-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/0\/04\/Make-Garlic-Knots-Step-1.jpg\/v4-190px-Make-Garlic-Knots-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":"190","bigHeight":"127","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} If you don't have cooking spray, you could use a pastry brush to lightly oil the sheet.

steps.headline: Combine the garlic butter mixture.
steps.description: Melt 1/4 cup (55 g) unsalted butter in a small bowl and stir in 2 tablespoons freshly grated Parmesan, 3/4 teaspoon garlic powder, 1/2 teaspoon dried oregano, 1/2 teaspoon dried parsley flakes, and 1/4 teaspoon salt. You can set the mixture aside while you roll the knots.

steps.headline: Roll and tie the biscuits into knots.
steps.description: Open one 16-ounce (462 g) tube of refrigerated buttermilk biscuits. Cut each of the 8 biscuits in half, so you get 16 pieces of dough. Roll each piece of dough into a rope that's 5-inches (13 cm) long. Tie the rope into a simple knot and tuck the ends under. Repeat this for each piece of dough. Don't worry if the knots don't look perfect. As long as they're formed into a rough knot-shape, they'll bake up well.

steps.headline: Brush the knots with the garlic butter.
steps.description: Set the knots of dough on the prepared baking sheet. Dip a pastry brush into the garlic butter mixture and spread it over each knot. You won't use all of the garlic butter mixture. Save the rest for brushing on the knots after they've baked.

steps.headline: Bake the garlic knots.
steps.description: Put the baking sheet in the oven and bake the garlic knots for 8 to 10 minutes. Once the knots are golden brown, carefully remove them from the oven and brush them with the rest of the garlic butter mixture. Serve the garlic knots right away or cool them on a wire rack. Store the cooled knots in an airtight container for several days.

steps.headline: Whisk the dry dough ingredients.
steps.description: Set a stand mixer on your counter. Measure 3 3/4 cups (525 g) of bread flour, 1 1/2 teaspoons of granulated sugar, 1 envelope (2 1/2 teaspoons or 7 g) of active dry yeast, and 2 teaspoons of salt into the mixing bowl. Whisk the dry ingredients, so the yeast is incorporated.

steps.headline: Beat in the water and olive oil.
steps.description: Put the dough hook attachment on the mixer and turn the mixer on to low. Beat in 1 1/2 cups (350 ml) of warm water [110 to 115 degrees F (43 to 46 C)] and 2 tablespoons of the olive oil on low speed. Keep beating the dough on low speed until it gathers into a ball. You can add an extra tablespoon or two of flour, if the dough is very sticky. If the dough is too dry, add a tablespoon of warm water.

steps.headline: Knead and prove the dough.
steps.description: Sprinkle a little flour on the counter and scrape the dough onto it. Use the palms of your hand to knead the dough for a few minutes. It should become smooth and elastic. Spread the remaining 2 teaspoons of oil into a large bowl and set the dough ball in it. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and let it prove for 1 1/2 hours. It should double in volume. Let the dough prove, or rest, in a warm place. This will help the yeast activate and make the dough rise.

steps.headline: Divide the dough into pieces.
steps.description: Sprinkle a little flour on your work surface and scoop the dough onto it. Cut the dough into 2 large pieces and set them aside to rest for 10 minutes. Then take one of the pieces and cut it into 8 pieces. Repeat this with the other dough piece, so you end up with a total of 16 pieces. You may need to sprinkle the knife with a little flour to keep it from sticking to the dough.

steps.headline: Shape the dough pieces into knots.
steps.description: Sprinkle a little flour on each of the dough pieces and roll each piece between your palms to make individual balls. Roll each ball out to a rope. Twist each rope into a knot shape and put the knots on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. If you don't have parchment paper, you can spray the sheets with cooking spray.

steps.headline: Prove the knots and prepare the oven.
steps.description: Cover the baking sheet with plastic wrap and let the knots prove for 30 minutes. They should get a little larger in size as they rest. Turn the oven on to 450 degrees F (230 C).

steps.headline: Bake the knots.
steps.description: Remove the plastic wrap from the baking sheet and put the sheet in the preheated oven. Bake the knots for 20 minutes, so they become golden brown. Carefully remove them from the oven and let them cool a little while you make the garlic butter coating.

steps.headline: Make the garlic butter coating.
steps.description: Place 1 stick (113 g) of unsalted butter and 6 minced cloves of garlic into a small sauce pan. Turn the heat on to medium-low, so the butter melts. Simmer the garlic and butter for a few minutes and stir in 1/2 cup (15 g) of fresh minced parsley and 1 1/2 teaspoons of garlic salt. Turn off the heat.

steps.headline: Brush the baked knots with the coating.
steps.description: Dip a pastry brush in garlic butter mixture and brush it over the warm knots. Grate 1/4 cup (25 g) of Parmesan cheese and sprinkle it over the warm garlic knots. Serve the knots immediately or store them in an airtight container once they've cooled.

text:
Making Garlic Knots Using Refrigerated Biscuits Preheat the oven and prepare the sheets. Turn the oven on to 400 degrees F (200 C). Get out a baking sheet and spray it with cooking spray or line with parchment paper. This will prevent the garlic knots from sticking. Set the sheet aside while you make the garlic knots. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/04\/Make-Garlic-Knots-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/0\/04\/Make-Garlic-Knots-Step-1.jpg\/v4-190px-Make-Garlic-Knots-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":"190","bigHeight":"127","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} If you don't have cooking spray, you could use a pastry brush to lightly oil the sheet. Combine the garlic butter mixture. Melt 1/4 cup (55 g) unsalted butter in a small bowl and stir in 2 tablespoons freshly grated Parmesan, 3/4 teaspoon garlic powder, 1/2 teaspoon dried oregano, 1/2 teaspoon dried parsley flakes, and 1/4 teaspoon salt. You can set the mixture aside while you roll the knots. Roll and tie the biscuits into knots. Open one 16-ounce (462 g) tube of refrigerated buttermilk biscuits. Cut each of the 8 biscuits in half, so you get 16 pieces of dough. Roll each piece of dough into a rope that's 5-inches (13 cm) long. Tie the rope into a simple knot and tuck the ends under. Repeat this for each piece of dough. Don't worry if the knots don't look perfect. As long as they're formed into a rough knot-shape, they'll bake up well. Brush the knots with the garlic butter. Set the knots of dough on the prepared baking sheet. Dip a pastry brush into the garlic butter mixture and spread it over each knot. You won't use all of the garlic butter mixture. Save the rest for brushing on the knots after they've baked. Bake the garlic knots. Put the baking sheet in the oven and bake the garlic knots for 8 to 10 minutes. Once the knots are golden brown, carefully remove them from the oven and brush them with the rest of the garlic butter mixture. Serve the garlic knots right away or cool them on a wire rack. Store the cooled knots in an airtight container for several days. Making Garlic Knots From Scratch Whisk the dry dough ingredients. Set a stand mixer on your counter. Measure 3 3/4 cups (525 g) of bread flour, 1 1/2 teaspoons of granulated sugar, 1 envelope (2 1/2 teaspoons or 7 g) of active dry yeast, and 2 teaspoons of salt into the mixing bowl. Whisk the dry ingredients, so the yeast is incorporated. Beat in the water and olive oil. Put the dough hook attachment on the mixer and turn the mixer on to low. Beat in 1 1/2 cups (350 ml) of warm water [110 to 115 degrees F (43 to 46 C)] and 2 tablespoons of the olive oil on low speed. Keep beating the dough on low speed until it gathers into a ball. You can add an extra tablespoon or two of flour, if the dough is very sticky. If the dough is too dry, add a tablespoon of warm water. Knead and prove the dough. Sprinkle a little flour on the counter and scrape the dough onto it. Use the palms of your hand to knead the dough for a few minutes. It should become smooth and elastic. Spread the remaining 2 teaspoons of oil into a large bowl and set the dough ball in it. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and let it prove for 1 1/2 hours. It should double in volume. Let the dough prove, or rest, in a warm place. This will help the yeast activate and make the dough rise. Divide the dough into pieces. Sprinkle a little flour on your work surface and scoop the dough onto it. Cut the dough into 2 large pieces and set them aside to rest for 10 minutes. Then take one of the pieces and cut it into 8 pieces. Repeat this with the other dough piece, so you end up with a total of 16 pieces. You may need to sprinkle the knife with a little flour to keep it from sticking to the dough. Shape the dough pieces into knots. Sprinkle a little flour on each of the dough pieces and roll each piece between your palms to make individual balls. Roll each ball out to a rope. Twist each rope into a knot shape and put the knots on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. If you don't have parchment paper, you can spray the sheets with cooking spray. Prove the knots and prepare the oven. Cover the baking sheet with plastic wrap and let the knots prove for 30 minutes. They should get a little larger in size as they rest. Turn the oven on to 450 degrees F (230 C). Bake the knots. Remove the plastic wrap from the baking sheet and put the sheet in the preheated oven. Bake the knots for 20 minutes, so they become golden brown. Carefully remove them from the oven and let them cool a little while you make the garlic butter coating. Make the garlic butter coating. Place 1 stick (113 g) of unsalted butter and 6 minced cloves of garlic into a small sauce pan. Turn the heat on to medium-low, so the butter melts. Simmer the garlic and butter for a few minutes and stir in 1/2 cup (15 g) of fresh minced parsley and 1 1/2 teaspoons of garlic salt. Turn off the heat. Brush the baked knots with the coating. Dip a pastry brush in garlic butter mixture and brush it over the warm knots. Grate 1/4 cup (25 g) of Parmesan cheese and sprinkle it over the warm garlic knots. Serve the knots immediately or store them in an airtight container once they've cooled.
